thread.title: 5 of the Best Butternut Squash Recipes for Fall
thread.title_full: 5 of the Best Butternut Squash Recipes for Fall

author: Alison Cooper
title: 5 of the Best Butternut Squash Recipes for Fall
text:
Key Takeaways
- Roasted butternut squash soup is a creamy, dairy-free fall favorite with caramelized flavors.
- Butternut squash kale salad offers a tangy and hearty salad using fresh seasonal ingredients.
- Elevated mac and cheese with butternut squash is a comforting twist with added nutrients and creaminess.
When the fall season arrives, winter squashes of all shapes and sizes start popping up on grocery store shelves and markets across the country. And of course, one of the most popular and sought-after fall vegetables is none other than butternut squash! A versatile veggie, butternut squash adds fall flavor to your meals with its sweet yet nutty taste, velvety texture, and vivid orange hue. While it may be low in calories, it certainly does not lack flavor, while incorporating vital nutrients into your diet, like vitamin A, vitamin C, potassium, magnesium, manganese, fiber, and more.
Experiment with five butternut squash recipes that are a must-try for fall. Add fall recipes to your weekly roundup for festive homemade dishes that use fresh, seasonal ingredients.
1 Rich and Creamy Butternut Squash Soup
Caramelize your squash, onion, and garlic in the oven for added flavor
A rich and creamy soup without any dairy products, roasted butternut squash soup is a classic choice for fall with comforting spices and simple ingredients. Roasting the squash (alongside onion and garlic) adds a depth of flavor to your soup as it caramelizes in the oven, bringing out its naturally sweet flavor. After roasting, toss everything into a high-powered blender for an easy meal that requires little effort!
To make roasted squash soup, gather some ingredients first.
- One large butternut squash
- 1 tablespoon of avocado oil
- One onion, cut in half
- Two garlic cloves
- ½ tablespoon of maple syrup
- ¼ teaspoon of ground nutmeg
- ¼ teaspoon of ground ginger
- 3 to 4 cups of vegetable broth
- 1 teaspoon of salt
- Freshly ground black pepper
Step 1: |
Preheat your oven to 425 degrees Fahrenheit. Using a sharp knife, slice your squash in half lengthwise and scoop out any seeds. Drizzle with avocado oil, salt, and pepper. Place on a baking sheet, cut side down and roast for about 50 to 60 minutes. |
Step 2: |
After 30 minutes, add the cut onion and garlic cloves (wrapped in tin foil with a drizzle of oil) and continue roasting. |
Step 3: |
Remove everything from the oven and allow it to cool for a few minutes. Using a large spoon, scoop the flesh from the butternut squash and transfer to a blender. Add in the roasted onion, garlic, salt, maple syrup, spices, and 3 cups of vegetable broth. Blend on high for 1 to 2 minutes, until you reach a smooth consistency. If the soup is too thick, add another cup of broth. |
Step 4: |
Serve your soup in bowls and garnish with freshly cracked pepper, roasted seeds, and fresh chives. |
Don't toss out the seeds! After slicing and scooping the seeds from your squash, roast them in a frying pan with butter until slightly toasted. Sprinkle on top of your soup before serving for a crunchy, salty addition that is similar to pumpkin seeds.
2 Healthy and Hearty Butternut Squash Kale Salad
Utilize fresh seasonal produce in this tasty salad recipe
Using seasonal fall produce, switch up your typical salad routine with a hearty fall salad recipe! Butternut squash is the star of the show in this tangy salad, which combines creamy goat cheese, crisp kale, and fresh pomegranate seeds, all tossed in a bright and citrusy vinaigrette.
Salad Ingredients:
To make your kale salad, gather your fresh ingredients.
- 4 cups of butternut squash, cut into cubes
- 1 teaspoon of olive oil
- Three garlic cloves, minced
- ½ teaspoon of ground turmeric
- ¼ teaspoon of sea salt
- 1 large bunch of Tuscan kale
- ¼ cup of thinly sliced red onion
- ⅓ cup of pomegranate seeds
- ¼ cup of toasted sliced almonds
- ¼ cup of goat cheese, crumbled
Vinaigrette Ingredients:
To make your citrus dressing, gather some different materials.
- 2 tablespoons of olive oil
- 1 tablespoon of freshly squeezed orange juice
- 1 tablespoon of apple cider vinegar
- 1 teaspoon of Dijon mustard
- 1 teaspoon of honey
- Salt and pepper to taste
Step 1: |
Preheat your oven to 400 degrees Fahrenheit and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. |
Step 2: |
In a large bowl, toss the cubed squash with olive oil, minced garlic, turmeric, and salt. Transfer to the baking sheet, spacing the squash evenly, and roast for 20 minutes, flipping halfway. Afterward, remove it from the oven and allow it to cool slightly. |
Step 3: |
While the squash is roasting, wash and roughly chop your kale, remove the stems, and add to a large bowl. |
Step 4: |
Next, prepare your homemade vinaigrette. Add all the ingredients to a small bowl and whisk to combine. Pour the dressing over the chopped kale, and gently massage it into the leaves for several minutes, which helps to remove any bitterness. |
Step 5: |
Add the roasted squash, red onion, and pomegranate seeds to the salad, mixing to combine. Serve in salad bowls, topping each bowl with a generous crumble of goat cheese and almond slices. |
3 Elevated Mac and Cheese with Butternut Squash
Take your comfort food up a notch by sneaking in veggies
Another one of the best butternut squash recipes to try making this fall is an elevated mac and cheese. Oozing with cheesy goodness and all the fall flavor, this baked mac and cheese is a unique take on the classic pasta dish you know and love. Butternut squash adds a healthy, nutritious kick and extra creaminess, along with a subtly sweet and nutty flavor profile that is sure to impress.
To make an elevated mac and cheese, gather your hearty ingredients.
- 1 pound of butternut squash, cut into cubes
- One shallot, roughly chopped
- 1 ½ cups of vegetable broth
- 1 tablespoon butter
- 10 ounces of elbow macaroni noodles
- ½ teaspoon of onion powder
- ½ teaspoon of garlic powder
- ¼ cup panko breadcrumbs
- 2 tablespoons of freshly grated Parmesan cheese
- ¼ cup of all-purpose flour
- 2 cups of milk
- ½ cup shredded Gruyère cheese
- ½ cup shredded cheddar cheese
- Chopped chives for garnish
- Salt and pepper
Step 1: |
Preheat your oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit. Spray a 9-inch by 11-inch glass baking dish with oil and set aside. In a small bowl, combine the breadcrumbs and Parmesan cheese, and set aside for later. |
Step 2: |
In a large pot, bring salted water to a boil and add your squash. Cook until soft, about 6 to 8 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the squash to a blender. Add in ½ cup vegetable broth, onion powder, garlic powder, 1 teaspoon of salt, and black pepper. Blend together until smooth and creamy. |
Step 3: |
Using the same boiling water, add your pasta and cook according to the package directions. Once al dente, strain and add the pasta back into the pot. |
Step 4: |
In a small pot, melt the butter and add your shallots. Sauté for about 2 minutes, then sprinkle with flour, and cook for an additional minute. Whisk in the remaining 1 cup of broth and milk. Bring to a boil, stirring frequently, then reduce the heat to low. Slowly whisk in the cheese, puréed squash, and 1½ teaspoons of salt and pepper until thick and creamy. |
Step 5: |
Add the cheese sauce to your noodles and stir well until evenly combined. Transfer to your glass baking dish, top with the breadcrumb mixture, and bake for 25 minutes. Broil on high for the last 2 to 3 minutes until golden brown on top. Garnish with fresh chives. |
4 Simple and Easy Roasted Butternut Squash
Roasting squash enhances its naturally sweet flavor
One of the quickest and easiest fall recipes is slicing your butternut squash into small bite-sized cubes and roasting them in the oven for a delicious side that is similar to sweet potatoes. Combining flavors like maple syrup, cinnamon, and fresh rosemary takes this simple side dish to the next level, bursting with seasonal fall flavor. Toss the squash in olive oil and allow it to caramelize in the oven for a rich, nutty taste that will have you coming back for seconds or thirds!
For a simple and healthy side dish, grab your ingredients and get started!
- One large butternut squash, cut into 1-inch cubes
- 1½ tablespoons of olive oil
- 1 tablespoon of maple syrup
- 1 teaspoon of sea salt
- ¾ teaspoon ground cinnamon
- ½ teaspoon ground black pepper
- 1 tablespoon of chopped fresh rosemary
Step 1: |
Preheat your oven to 400 degrees Fahrenheit and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. |
Step 2: |
In a large bowl, add the cubed squash, olive oil, maple syrup, cinnamon, salt, and pepper. Toss until everything is evenly coated and then transfer to the baking sheet, spacing the cubes evenly. |
Step 3: |
Bake for 15 minutes, then flip the squash, and return to the oven. Continue baking for another 10 to 15 minutes. Remove from the oven and sprinkle with fresh rosemary. |
Serve roasted butternut squash alongside seasonal fall veggies and a protein of your choice, such as chicken, beef, or pork.
5 Homemade Butternut Squash Ravioli
Little pockets of creamy, savory goodness
Calling all pasta lovers! Don't be intimidated by this ravioli recipe, which features homemade pasta that is stuffed with butternut squash, garlic, and sage for the ultimate fall comfort food. While it is a bit more time-consuming, it's definitely worth it for these little pockets of goodness coated in a brown butter sage sauce that simply melts in your mouth!
For the Pasta:
To make this homemade ravioli, gather the following ingredients.
- 1 ½ cups of Semolina pasta flour
- 1 ½ cups of all-purpose flour
- 4 tablespoons of olive oil
- 4 tablespoons of water
- 1 teaspoon of kosher salt
- Four whole eggs
For the Filling:
You'll need a different set of ingredients of the filling.
- 2 ½ pounds of butternut squash, cut into cubes
- Eight whole garlic cloves
- ¼ cup of olive oil
- ½ cup of Parmesan cheese
- ½ teaspoon of dried sage
- Salt and pepper to taste
For the Sauce:
Don't forget the sauce!
- 4 tablespoons of butter
- Ten fresh sage leaves
Step 1: |
Start by making your homemade pasta. Combine all the pasta dough ingredients together to make a stiff dough, kneading by hand until the dough reaches an elastic consistency. Wrap the dough in plastic wrap and allow it to rest for 20 minutes. |
Step 2: |
Next, prepare the filling. Toss the cubed squash and garlic in olive oil and transfer to a baking sheet. Roast at 400 degrees Fahrenheit for 30 to 40 minutes. Once fork tender, remove from the oven and transfer everything to a food processor. Pulse until combined, then slowly pour in the olive oil, until you reach a smooth consistency. Add in the Parmesan cheese, dried sage, salt, and pepper, and pulse to combine. |
Step 3: |
After allowing the dough to rest, lightly flour your table, then roll out the dough to your desired thickness. To assemble your ravioli, lay out a thin sheet of dough and add 1 teaspoon of filling, spacing 1 to 2 inches apart. Using a pastry brush, lightly brush around each piece (to help seal the edges) and add another sheet of dough on top, pressing firmly on all sides. Using a crimping-style pasta cutter, cut between the mounds to form squares. Alternatively, you can use a ravioli press to seal the edges for you. |
Step 4: |
To make your pasta sauce, melt the butter in a small pot and add fresh sage leaves. Leave on low heat and allow the sage to |
Step 5: |
Next, boil a large pot with salted water and add your ravioli. Using a slotted spoon, carefully remove the ravioli from the water once they float, about 2 to 3 minutes. Toss in the brown butter sauce, top with additional Parmesan cheese, and enjoy! |
Add Seasonal Fall Flavor with Butternut Squash
When it comes to butternut squash recipes, the options feel endless, with so many unique and flavorful ways to use this versatile fall veggie. Experiment with fall recipes and try a batch of butternut squash soup, make an elevated version of mac and cheese or ravioli, roast your squash with seasonal spices, or whip up a filling kale salad. With beneficial vitamins and minerals, enjoy the sweet yet savory taste of butternut squash by adding it to your shopping list this autumn!
